title: This Pratt architecture student project mines the Sea Ranch for fire resilient space solutions
author: Josh Niland
excerpt: With spring graduations fast approaching, it’s an apt time to highlight some student work from the past semester. Today, we’ll take a look at Pratt School of Architecture Class of 2025 M.Arch Genevieve Garlock and her research into fire mitigation strategies using the Sea Ranch as a case...
text: anchor From 'Wildfire-Resilient Planning in Sea Ranch' by Genevieve Garlock (Pratt Institute). Image courtesy Genevieve Garlock With spring graduations fast approaching, it’s an apt time to highlight some student work from the past semester.  Today, we’ll take a look at Pratt School of Architecture Class of 2025 M.Arch Genevieve Garlock and her research into fire mitigation strategies using the Sea Ranch as a case study. From 'Wildfire-Resilient Planning in Sea Ranch' by Genevieve Garlock (Pratt Institute). Image courtesy Genevieve GarlockDefensible space design is of particular importance in the context of subdivisions in California, as the threat from wildfires places more pressure on architects to deliver resilient and ecologically responsible shelter to people in those areas. Instructor Jeffrey Inaba says that the overlapping of spaces foster a better sense of shared space and community integration. From 'Wildfire-Resilient Planning in Sea Ranch' by Genevieve Garlock (Pratt Institute). Image courtesy Genevieve Garlock The project is meant to occupy Lot 39B on the Sea Ranch. Garlock says the design works to "investigate the structure of residential neighborhoods and intertwines issues of fire defensibility, privacy, and land ownership to create a new type of neighborhood and residence that fosters neighborly connection and fire protection." From 'Wildfire-Resilient Planning in Sea Ranch' by Genevieve Garlock (Pratt Institute). Image courtesy Genevieve Garlock Garlock, who completed her undergraduate studies at Princeton in 2020, was inspired to resolve a challenge inherent in subdivision design that results when property lines overlap with fire hardening zones. In doing so, her work also forges the possibility for new understanding how shared responsibility, resources, and whether it is best to care for property in a collective or as private individuals.  From 'Wildfire-Resilient Planning in Sea Ranch' by Genevieve Garlock (Pratt Institute). Image courtesy Genevieve Garlock Existing planning standards dictate that properties be spaced 30 feet apart, while the definition for a "defensible" boundary is approximately 100 feet. By converting the overlapping spaces into programmable shared easements between neighbors, Garlock says, residents will be compelled into taking better responsibility for their stewardship and thus foster community. From 'Wildfire-Resilient Planning in Sea Ranch' by Genevieve Garlock (Pratt Institute). Image courtesy Genevieve Garlock She says the design of the homes themselves must also be reconsidered in this context, maintaining the possibility for comfortable and private living while galvanizing the homeowners to create a more secure their neighbors and themselves. From 'Wildfire-Resilient Planning in Sea Ranch' by Genevieve Garlock (Pratt Institute). Image courtesy Genevieve Garlock"This project was started in September of 2024 and completed in early December of 2024, one month before the start of the LA fires. Although this project is not a direct response to this specific tragedy, there was a very clear sense of urgency from previous wildfire events," she explained to Archinect. "Throughout the studio, we were taught that due to factors such as climate change, forest fires in California are happening at a more alarming rate, exponentially growing in frequency, scale, and destruction. Before schematic design began, we spent several weeks researching the patterns, effects, and responses to forest fires as well as mapping the increased size and frequency of forest fires in California over the past several years." You can learn more about another wildfire-related research studio led by Jeffrey Inaba with Hitoishi Abe at the UCLA AUD in 2021 here.
html:
• anchor

    From 'Wildfire-Resilient Planning in Sea Ranch' by Genevieve Garlock (Pratt Institute). Image courtesy Genevieve Garlock

    With spring graduations fast approaching, it’s an apt time to highlight some student work from the past semester. 

    Today, we’ll take a look at Pratt School of Architecture Class of 2025 M.Arch Genevieve Garlock and her research into fire mitigation strategies using the Sea Ranch as a case study.

    Defensible space design is of particular importance in the context of subdivisions in California, as the threat from wildfires places more pressure on architects to deliver resilient and ecologically responsible shelter to people in those areas. Instructor Jeffrey Inaba says that the overlapping of spaces foster a better sense of shared space and community integration.

    The project is meant to occupy Lot 39B on the Sea Ranch. Garlock says the design works to "investigate the structure of residential neighborhoods and intertwines issues of fire defensibility, privacy, and land ownership to create a new type of neighborhood and residence that fosters neighborly connection and fire protection."

    Garlock, who completed her undergraduate studies at Princeton in 2020, was inspired to resolve a challenge inherent in subdivision design that results when property lines overlap with fire hardening zones. In doing so, her work also forges the possibility for new understanding how shared responsibility, resources, and whether it is best to care for property in a collective or as private individuals. 

    Existing planning standards dictate that properties be spaced 30 feet apart, while the definition for a "defensible" boundary is approximately 100 feet. By converting the overlapping spaces into programmable shared easements between neighbors, Garlock says, residents will be compelled into taking better responsibility for their stewardship and thus foster community.

    She says the design of the homes themselves must also be reconsidered in this context, maintaining the possibility for comfortable and private living while galvanizing the homeowners to create a more secure their neighbors and themselves.

    "This project was started in September of 2024 and completed in early December of 2024, one month before the start of the LA fires. Although this project is not a direct response to this specific tragedy, there was a very clear sense of urgency from previous wildfire events," she explained to Archinect. "Throughout the studio, we were taught that due to factors such as climate change, forest fires in California are happening at a more alarming rate, exponentially growing in frequency, scale, and destruction. Before schematic design began, we spent several weeks researching the patterns, effects, and responses to forest fires as well as mapping the increased size and frequency of forest fires in California over the past several years."

    You can learn more about another wildfire-related research studio led by Jeffrey Inaba with Hitoishi Abe at the UCLA AUD in 2021 here.
